greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Smallest m such that GCD[a+b,a-b]=n, where a=sigma[n],b=phi[n].
example: n=10,a(10)=328, sigma[328]=630,phi[328]=160, sigma(328)+phi(328)=790, sigma(328)-phi(328)=470, GCD[790,470]=10-n; for n=odd number, a[n] should be either a square or twice a square and so quicker search for large values is possible, like e.g. for n=97:a[97]=m=190077688441=435979^2 is the smallest solution.
mathematica: f[x_] := Apply[GCD, {DivisorSigma[1, x]+EulerPhi[x], DivisorSigma[1, x]-EulerPhi[x]}] t=Table[0, {100}]; Do[s=f[n]; If[s<101&&t[[s]]==0, t[[s]]=n], {n, 1, 10^13}];
results.author: _Labos Elemer_, Nov 12 2002
